okay so I thought I would share some of the main reasons that we're finding why
so many customers are moving to the cloud and why they're doing it so quickly and there are a few benefits
that we hear frequently from customers that they would cite as the most important reasons the first thing is if you can
trade Capital expense for variable expense that's very attractive instead
of having to lay out all those all that capital for data centers and servers before you know how you're going to use
them and if you don't have to do that instead just pay as you consume resource on a variable basis that's very
appealing and on top of trading Capital expense for variable expense customers
love the fact that in the cloud they get to pay a lower variable expense than they can do on their own and that's
because AWS is able to take its very large scale and pass pass those on to customers in the form of lower prices
and you can see some customer examples on this slide Samsung saved over $34
million in moving their Smart Hub application to AWS one of the largest banks in
Australia the Commonwealth Bank of Australia saved tens of millions of dollars in the first dozen apps they
moved to AWS and for square is saving 50% on their ATA Linux apps and then
recently IDC did a study where they looked at 12 companies and looked at their usage of infrastructure on
premises versus an AWS and then did a five-year TCO analysis and found that
they save 70% if they move to the cloud and we have this very interesting
virtuous circle going on which is as we have more customers who use AWS more it
means we have to go buy more infrastructure but as we buy more infrastructure we get economies of scale
which lower our infrastructure costs and as we lower our infrastructure costs we're able to lower our prices to
customers which drives more customers so it's a very useful uh virtuous circle for both customers and for
AWS and then it turns out that you can inject energy into this flywheel so as
we add new services and new features and as we expand our Global footprint and as
we continue to part partner with our very large and growing ecos system so that more companies can run the
applications they want to run on AWS and more companies get help from system integrators to actually get moving to
the cloud it turns out that we're able to spin that flywheel faster and as
we're able to continue to innovate on our infrastructure so in our data centers and on our Network and with
Hardware we're able to get better economies of scale which lets us lower our infrastructure costs lower our
prices and again spin the wheel going faster and you've seen this bear out as
we have lowered prices on 23 different occasions in the last few years largely in the of any competitive pressure to do
so and actually I have one more price reduction to talk about uh I'm excited
to tell you guys that we are lowering the price for Amazon simple storage
service Amazon S3 by about 25% across the board here you can
see here you can see uh the US Standard region this is just an example but you can see the tiers all going down from
about 24 to 28% and that's true in all the regions so we're excited to share that news with you
today the third thing that customers tell us that they really like about the cloud is that they don't have to guess
on capacity anymore so any of you that have tried to launch a new project know
that you have to guess what your capacity is going to be and that's actually really hard to do without knowing what the customer response is
and and so what happens is you end up making some projection represented by the green dotted line and the actual
usage is often something like the solid white line and what that means is that in the beginning you actually are
sitting on a lot of wasted capital and resource until your application takes off and then if it does you're left with
Too Short capacity and you either have to decide to provide a bad customer experience which most people don't
choose or you have to run around like a chicken with your head cut off and find
somebody who can get you that infrastructure quickly and you almost always overpay and overcommit to do it
in the cloud that problem goes away you don't have to guess you provision as much Resource as you think you need
early on if it turns out you need more you seamlessly scale up if it turns out you don't need as much as you
provisioned at one point you just give it back to us and stop paying that's a very different model than the last 30
years the fourth thing customers tell us is that the cloud dramatically improves
how quickly they can get to Market with whatever applications they're thinking about in the old world if you if you
talk to an engineer and an Enterprise or a company and you ask them how long does it take you to provision a server for
something new or to put something in inte tag we got answers when we ask customers this that range from 6 to 20
weeks that's mading 6 to 20 weeks for a single server and what it does is it
just stifles Innovation people figure why bother if it's going to take so long just to to get a server in the cloud you
can provision completely on your own self-service you don't have to talk to anybody hundreds or even thousands of
servers in minutes and that really changes how quickly you can deploy
applications and you can see you know news limited used to have six teams
taking 56 days to set up a big development environment it's now one team in three days you can see that
Lions Gate went from weeks to hours to deploy and and and bamp Page can double their server capacity now in 20 seconds
and there was a recent IDC study that showed that it's actually five times more efficient Allin to use the cloud
and actually to do it on premises and I think that's frankly understating it but any company that does a lot of
innovation will tell you that there the two most important things are number one
being able to try a lot of experiments and number two if those experiments
don't work and many of them should not work if you're really pushing the envelope not to have to live with the
collateral damage of a failed experiment and in the cloud you can spin up thousands of instances in minutes so you
can try any experiments that you guys as a team come up with and if they don't work just give them back to us or use
them for other experiments you want to try really changes the game and how fast companies can move their businesses
forward the fifth thing we hear from customers is that they's scarce resource
in most companies is software development Engineers engineering teams have this long list of priorities and
projects that the company wants them to do and you're left with this unpleasant experience of having to try to
prioritize between them and those or decisions are really specious they're really hard to make the right ones we
know from the early days of Amazon it was near impossible if you can take that scarce resource who are software
development engineers and instead of having them focus on the infrastructure which is important but hardly ever
differentiates your business and instead have them focus on projects that move your mission or your business forward
that's a huge Advantage the sixth thing that we hear from our customers is that they like the
fact that they can provide a global high quality end user experience all over the world so virtually every company now
even startups from day one given the nature the internet and the mobile world we live in have Global end users and so
in the old world people would store their applications or run their applications in one data center or a
couple data centers in one geography and the idea of actually being closer to their Global end users seemed like a
nice to have but I don't know how I'm going to do it I I don't know who to rely on I don't know how to contract
with them I don't speak the language in some cases it just seems like it's not going to be easy to do and so most don't
but in the cloud the game changes you can have your application in any one of the nine regions AWS has all over the
world world and that means you can provide a lower latency experience for your customers which is a much better
end user customer experience so in summarizing the
benefits the main benefits of why people are moving so fast to the cloud it's that they get to change Capital expense
for variable expense pay a lower variable expense than they can do on their own they don't have to guess in
capacity they can move quicker which enables a lot more Innovation they get
to spend their scarce SD resource on projects that move the business forward and they can go Global with their
application presence in minutes what's interesting is when we
launched AWS and the cloud started to get some traction what we started hearing from Old Guard technology
companies was ah there's nothing new here this is just virtualization CL there's nothing new in the cloud and as
customers saw through that and realized that what AWS provides is a combination of soft Ware and hardware and data set
are all wrapped in a service the Old Guard technology companies kind of abandoned that line of
reging and then they said okay fine the cloud is different I'll give you that it's not virtualization but you can get
all the benefits of AWS in a private cloud in your own data center that's you
know that that was interesting too and what you started seeing was that these
companies started taking all of their existing products and fixing the world word cloud to them and said we have
Cloud products too you can do this in your own data center have at it but and what the industry started
calling this group of people that were attaching the word cloud to all the products and saying we have the cloud to
was Cloud washers and you have to be careful about who's telling you what and get into the details of what's being
offered and what's interesting is if you look at the benefits that I just spent a few minutes talking about on why people
are moving to the cloud they actually have nothing to do with the word cloud they have everything to
do with the actual benefits and then if you go look at the private Cloud they
actually have none of the benefits that I just mentioned you don't get to trade cap backs for variable expense you pay a
high fixed price not a variable expense you actually don't get elasticity as a company you don't get that Innovation
cycle and the mobility that and and speed to Market you still have to manage it with your own SD
and you can't go Global in minutes and for the few companies so far
that have actually implemented a private Cloud you can look at the benefits they were trying to achieve which by the way
is a fraction of the benefits I just mentioned on why people are moving to AWS and you can see the vast majority of
them aren't accomplishing the benefits they set out or the objectives they set out to accomplish with a private
Cloud so you ask yourself why are these Old Guard technology companies so
desperately trying to get you to buy the private Cloud why and I think the answer is that the
economics of what we're doing are extremely disruptive for Old Guard
technology companies these are companies that have lived on 60 to 80% gross
margins for many many years and in fact you can see that they you know they set
expectations that that's what they're doing and they you know this is what they communicate externally here are three quotes from the senior most people
at some of the largest Old Guard technology companies all Fortune 100 companies so here's the first one we can
achieve these record margins as an integrated hardware and software company because we are focusing on high margin
systems another CFO once again margin expansion was the
largest contributor to growth and then a third Who Says by
2016 we expect to be growing align with GDP with operating profit growing faster
than Revenue industry-leading margins and disciplined Capital allocation these
are actual quotes and these are the businesses that these companies like to run and have run for the last 30
years and high margin businesses have been around forever and in lots of
Industries and they're obviously a very valid and successful business model it's
just not ours it is radically different to run a 60 to 80% gross margin business
than a high volume low margin business and if you believe like we do that the vast majority of computing is moving to
the cloud over the next 10 years it stands to reason that cloud computing is going to be a high volume low margin
business now if you run a high volume low margin business versus a 60 to 80%
gross margin business you think about everything differently you think about your pricing differently you think about
your cost structure differently you think about where you spend your Innovation Cycles differently if you can
take cost out of your own cost structure whether you pocket those as more profit or give them back to customers in the
form of lower prices you think about that differently now Amazon every business that we run is a high volume
low margin business we like those businesses we're very comfortable running them and we have that DNA I
think most of the Old Guard technology companies who are running 60 to 80% gross margin businesses don't like those
types of businesses and it's why they're pushing the private Cloud so hard because it doesn't disrup disrupt their
existing business models but I think even those companies over time will see
that the world is moving the direction the AWS is pointing and then it will be interesting to see how many of those
companies will be good at operating high volume low margin businesses because you don't flip a switch overnight and become
great operating High volume low margin businesses they're completely different operating
characteristics so next up coming on stage is a CEO of a company that very
easily could have built their own private Cloud they are one of the most qualified and technically competent
